comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: In response  to Beachcomber's note - I read once that there were a number of warehouses on Kirribilli Point. A possibility?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] Found it! According to this 1917 interactive map it was the "Pastoral Ass[ociation] Wool Stores" - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview?pi=nla.map-gmod71-a3-sd&rg... What a strange place to build a wool store - probably why it did not last long.

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: That must have been the reference I had picked up in the past ... good detective work!

comment.author: 63385174@N06
comment._content: The Pastoral Finance Association Wool Stores had a major fire in 1921 which destroyed the building. Additional fire appliances had to be brought over from the city by vehicular ferry. The building was left a ruin for some years until apartments and the Hayes Street ferry wharf were established in the late 1920's.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Here's how this pic appeared in the Australian Town & Country Journal in June 1904 (...the bottom one)...the ferry isn't dodged out in the T&CJ version - nla.gov.au/nla.news-page5704086

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] That is interesting re the missing ferry. It means that these SRNSW prints are cropped a bit for some reason. The original glass negatives may well join up better than Don Shearman's reconstructions www.flickr.com/photos/donshearman/6805007159/

comment.author: 63385174@N06
comment._content: I would suggest that the boats have been added into the Australian Town & Country pics rather than the other way around. The perspective on the "missing" boats is not quite correct in the Town & Country pics.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/63385174@N06] That makes sense...if the ferry was edited out of this pic, then whoever did the processing did a remarkable patch up job on the sea...I reckon the T&CJ pic is taken from the assembled panorama...you can see the joins...one of which cuts across the stern of the ferry...given the gear used at the time (ie. they couldn't reel off 10 frames a second), I suspect that the moving ferries and other shipping would have posed a few problems when it came to piecing together the panorama...trying to ensure that the one ferry didn't appear in two places on the panorama...or that a ship wasn't caught at a join...maybe this ferry just made it onto the next pic to the right...I wonder how many frames a minute pros were able to reel off in 1904?
